And the messengers came in, and behold, the household idol was upon the bed, and the goats’ hair cushion at its head.
And Saul said to Michal, Why have you deceived me thus, and sent away my enemy, so that he has escaped? And Michal said to Saul, He said to me, Send me away; why should I put you to death?
Now David fled and escaped, and came to Samuel at Ramah, and told him all that Saul had done to him. And he and Samuel went and dwelt in Naioth.
And it was told Saul, saying, Behold, David is in Naioth in Ramah.

And Saul sent messengers to seize David, and they saw the company of the prophets prophesying, and Samuel standing as appointed over them; and the Spirit of God came upon the messengers of Saul, and they also prophesied.
And they told Saul, and he sent other messengers, and they also prophesied. And Saul again sent messengers a third time, and they also prophesied.
Then he also went to Ramah, and came to the great well that is in Secu; and he inquired and said, “Where are Samuel and David?” And one said, “Behold, they are at Naioth in Ramah.”
And he went there to Naioth in Ramah, and the Spirit of God came upon him also, and he went on and prophesied until he came to Naioth in Ramah.
And he also stripped off his garments and prophesied before Samuel, and fell down naked all that day and all that night. Therefore they say, “Is Saul also among the prophets?”
And David fled from Naioth in Ramah, and came and said before Jonathan, “What have I done? What is my iniquity, and what is my sin before your father, that he seeks my life?”
And he said to him, Far be it; you shall not die. Behold, my father will do nothing, great or small, without revealing it to my ear; and why should my father hide this thing from me? It is not so.

And David swore again and said, Your father surely knows that I have found favor in your eyes, and he has said, “Let not Jonathan know this, lest he be grieved.” But as the LORD lives, and as your soul lives, there is but a step between me and death.
Then Jonathan said to David, “Whatever your soul shall say, I will do for you.”
And David said to Jonathan, Behold, tomorrow is the new moon, and I should surely sit with the king to eat; but let me go, that I may hide myself in the field until the evening of the third day.
If your father should indeed miss me, then you shall say, “David earnestly asked leave of me to run to Bethlehem his city, for there is there the yearly sacrifice for all the family.”
If he says thus, “It is good,” it is well with your servant; but if he burns with anger, know that evil is fully determined by him.

And deal kindly with your servant, for you have brought your servant into a covenant of the LORD with you. But if there is in me iniquity, put me to death yourself; for why then should you bring me to your father?
And Jonathan said, Far be it from you; for if I surely know that evil is determined by my father to come upon you, then I will not fail to tell you.
And David said to Jonathan, Who will tell me, or what if your father answers you harshly?
And Jonathan said to David, Come, and let us go out into the field. And they both went out into the field.

And Jonathan said to David, “The LORD, the God of Israel, be witness: when I have sounded out my father about this time tomorrow, or on the third day, and behold, it is well toward David, shall I not then send to you and uncover your ear?”

Thus may the LORD do to Jonathan, and thus may he add, if my father intends evil against you and I do not reveal it to your ear and send you away, that you may go in peace. And may the LORD be with you, as he was with my father.
And if I am still alive, will you not show me the lovingkindness of the LORD, that I may not die?
And you shall not cut off your lovingkindness from my house forever, not even when the LORD cuts off the enemies of David, every one of them from the face of the earth.
So Jonathan made a covenant with the house of David, and the LORD shall require it at the hand of David’s enemies.
And Jonathan again made David swear, because of the love he had for him; for he loved him as he loved his own soul.
And Jonathan said to him, Tomorrow is the new moon, and you will be missed, for your seat will be empty.
And on the third day you shall go down swiftly and come to the place where you hid yourself on the day of the deed, and you shall remain beside the stone Ezel.
And I will shoot three arrows to the side of it, as though I shot at a mark.

And behold, I will send the lad, saying, Go, find the arrows. If I say indeed to the lad, Behold, the arrows are on this side of you, take them and come, for there is peace for you and no harm, as the LORD lives.
But if I say thus to the young man, Behold, the arrows are beyond you; go your way, for the LORD has sent you away.
And as for the matter which we have spoken, I and you, behold, the LORD is between me and you forever.
So David hid himself in the field, and the new moon came, and the king sat down at the table to eat.
And the king sat upon his seat, as at other times, on the seat by the wall; and Jonathan arose, and Abner sat by Saul’s side, but David’s place was empty.
And Saul spoke nothing that day, for he said, “It is by chance; he is not clean, surely he is not clean.”

And it came to pass on the next day, the second of the new moon, that the place of David was empty. And Saul said to Jonathan his son, Why has the son of Jesse not come to the meal, neither yesterday nor today?
And Jonathan answered Saul, “David earnestly asked leave of me to go to Bethlehem.”

And he said, Let me go, I pray, for we have a family sacrifice in the city, and my brother has commanded me to be there; and now, if I have found favor in your eyes, let me slip away, I pray, and see my brothers. Therefore he has not come to the king’s table.

Then Saul’s anger burned against Jonathan, and he said to him, “You son of a perverse, rebellious woman! Do I not know that you have chosen the son of Jesse to your own shame, and to the shame of your mother’s nakedness?”
For all the days that the son of Jesse lives upon the earth, you and your kingdom shall not be established. And now send and bring him to me, for he is a son of death.
And Jonathan answered Saul his father and said to him, “Why should he be put to death? What has he done?”
And Saul hurled the spear at him to strike him; then Jonathan knew that it was determined by his father to put David to death.
Then Jonathan rose up from the table in fierce anger, and he did not eat food on the second day of the new moon, for he was grieved for David, because his father had shamed him.
And it came to pass in the morning, that Jonathan went out into the field at the appointed time with David, and a little boy was with him.
And he said to his lad, Run, find now the arrows that I am shooting. The lad ran, and he shot the arrow beyond him.
And the boy came to the place of the arrow which Jonathan had shot, and Jonathan called after the boy and said, Is not the arrow beyond you?
And Jonathan called after the boy, “Make haste, hurry, do not stand still.” And Jonathan’s boy gathered up the arrows and came to his master.
But the lad knew nothing at all; only Jonathan and David knew the matter.
And Jonathan gave his weapons to the lad who was with him, and said to him, Go, carry them to the city.

The boy came, and David arose from beside the south, and fell on his face to the ground and bowed himself three times. And they kissed one another and wept with one another, until David wept the more.
And Jonathan said to David, Go in peace, for we have both sworn in the name of the LORD, saying, The LORD shall be between me and you, and between my seed and your seed, forever.
And he arose and went his way, and Jonathan came into the city.
And David came to Nob, to Ahimelech the priest. And Ahimelech trembled to meet David, and said to him, Why are you alone, and no man with you?

And David said to Ahimelech the priest, “The king has commanded me a matter, and he said to me, ‘Let no man know anything of the matter about which I send you, and with which I have commanded you.’ And the young men I have directed to such and such a place.”
Now therefore, what is under your hand? Give into my hand five loaves of bread, or whatever is found.
And the priest answered David and said, There is no common bread under my hand, but there is holy bread, if only the young men have kept themselves at least from woman.

And David answered the priest and said to him, “Indeed, woman has been kept from us since yesterday and the day before, when I went out, and the young men’s vessels were holy, though it was a common journey; how much more then today shall their vessels be holy.”

So the priest gave him holy bread, for there was no bread there except the bread of the Presence, which had been removed from before the LORD, to put hot bread in its place on the day it was taken away.
Now a certain man of the servants of Saul was there that day, detained before the LORD, and his name was Doeg the Edomite, the chief of the herdsmen that belonged to Saul.
And David said to Ahimelech, “Is there not here under your hand a spear or a sword? For neither my sword nor my weapons have I taken in my hand, because the king’s matter was urgent.”

And the priest said, “The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you struck down in the Valley of Elah, behold, it is here wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod. If you will take that for yourself, take it, for there is no other here except it.” And David said, “There is none like it; give it to me.”
Then David arose and fled that day from before Saul, and came to Achish king of Gath.
And the servants of Achish said to him, Is not this David, the king of the land? Is it not of him they sang in dances, saying, Saul has struck down his thousands, and David his ten thousands?
And David took these words to heart, and was very afraid of Achish king of Gath.
So he changed his behavior before their eyes and raved in their hands, and he scribbled on the doors of the gate, and let his spittle run down upon his beard.
Then Achish said to his servants, Behold, you see the man is mad; why then have you brought him to me?
Am I in want of madmen, that you have brought this one to rave before me? Shall this one come into my house?
And David departed from there and escaped to the cave of Adullam; and when his brothers and all his father’s house heard of it, they went down to him there.
And everyone in distress, and everyone who was in debt, and everyone bitter of soul gathered themselves to him; and he became captain over them, and there were with him about four hundred men.
And David went from there to Mizpeh of Moab, and he said to the king of Moab, “Let my father and my mother, I pray, come forth and be with you, until I know what God will do for me.”
And he brought them before the king of Moab, and they dwelt with him all the while that David was in the stronghold.
And Gad the prophet said to David, “Do not remain in the stronghold; depart, and go into the land of Judah.” So David went and came to the forest of Hereth.

And Saul heard that David was known, and the men that were with him. Now Saul was sitting in Gibeah under the tamarisk tree on the height, with his spear in his hand, and all his servants were standing about him.

And Saul said to his servants who stood about him, “Hear now, sons of Benjamin: will the son of Jesse also give to all of you fields and vineyards? Will he make all of you commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds?”

For all of you have conspired against me, and there is none who reveals to my ear when my son makes a covenant with the son of Jesse, and none of you is grieved for me or reveals to my ear that my son has stirred up my servant against me, to lie in wait, as at this day.
Then answered Doeg the Edomite, who stood over the servants of Saul, and said, I saw the son of Jesse coming to Nob, to Ahimelech the son of Ahitub.
And he inquired of the LORD for him, and gave him provisions, and gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine.
Then the king sent to summon Ahimelech son of Ahitub the priest, and all his father’s house, the priests who were in Nob; and they all came to the king.
And Saul said, Hear now, son of Ahitub. And he said, Here I am, my lord.

And Saul said to him, Why have you conspired against me, you and the son of Jesse, in that you have given him bread and a sword, and have inquired of God for him, that he should rise up against me, to lie in wait, as at this day?
And Ahimelech answered the king and said, “And who among all your servants is as faithful as David, the king’s son-in-law, and commander of your guard, and honored in your house?”

Today have I begun to inquire of God for him? Far be it from me. Let not the king lay anything upon his servant, nor upon all my father’s house, for your servant knew nothing of all this, little or great.
And the king said, You shall surely die, Ahimelech, you and all your father’s house.

And the king said to the runners that stood about him, “Turn and put to death the priests of the LORD, for their hand also is with David, and because they knew that he fled and did not reveal it to my ears.” But the servants of the king were not willing to stretch out their hand to strike the priests of the LORD.
And the king said to Doeg, “Turn, you, and fall upon the priests.” And Doeg the Edomite turned and fell upon the priests, and he slew on that day eighty and five men who wore a linen ephod.
And Nob, the city of the priests, he struck with the edge of the sword, from man even to woman, from infant even to nursing child, and ox and donkey and sheep, with the edge of the sword.
But one son of Ahimelech son of Ahitub escaped, and his name was Abiathar; and he fled after David.
And Abiathar told David that Saul had slain the priests of the LORD.
And David said to Abiathar, I knew on that day, when Doeg the Edomite was there, that he would surely tell Saul; I have brought about the death of all the persons of your father’s house.
Stay with me; do not fear, for he who seeks my life seeks your life also; for with me you shall be in safekeeping.
And they told David, saying, Behold, the Philistines are fighting against Keilah, and they are plundering the threshing floors.
And David inquired of the LORD, saying, “Shall I go and strike these Philistines?” And the LORD said to David, “Go, and you shall strike the Philistines and save Keilah.”
And David’s men said to him, Behold, we are afraid here in Judah; how much more then if we go to Keilah against the battle lines of the Philistines?
And David inquired yet again of the LORD, and the LORD answered him and said, Arise, go down to Keilah, for I am giving the Philistines into your hand.
So David went, he and his men, to Keilah and fought with the Philistines, and drove off their livestock, and struck them with a great slaughter. Thus David saved the inhabitants of Keilah.
And it came to pass, when Abiathar son of Ahimelech fled to David to Keilah, that the ephod came down in his hand.
And it was told Saul that David had come to Keilah, and Saul said, “God has delivered him into my hand, for he is shut in by entering into a city with gates and bars.”
And Saul summoned all the people to war, to go down to Keilah, to besiege David and his men.
And David knew that Saul was devising evil against him, and he said to Abiathar the priest, “Bring near the ephod.”
And David said, O LORD God of Israel, your servant has surely heard that Saul seeks to come to Keilah to destroy the city for my sake.
Will the men of Keilah deliver me into his hand? Will Saul come down, as your servant has heard? O LORD, God of Israel, tell your servant, I pray. And the LORD said, “He will come down.”
And David said, “Will the men of Keilah deliver me and my men into the hand of Saul?” And the LORD said, “They will deliver.”

Then David arose and his men, about six hundred, and they went out from Keilah and went wherever they could go. And it was told Saul that David had escaped from Keilah, and he ceased from going out after him.
And David dwelt in the wilderness in the strongholds, and he remained in the hill country in the wilderness of Ziph. And Saul sought him every day, but God did not deliver him into his hand.
And David saw that Saul had come out to seek his life, and David was in the wilderness of Ziph, in the forest.
And Jonathan, Saul’s son, arose and went to David at Horesh, and strengthened his hand in God.
And he said to him, Do not fear, for the hand of Saul my father shall not find you, and you shall reign over Israel, and I shall be second to you; and Saul my father also knows this.
And the two of them made a covenant before the LORD. And David remained in the forest, and Jonathan went to his house.
Then the Ziphites went up to Saul at Gibeah, saying, “Is not David hiding himself among us in the strongholds in the forest, on the hill of Hachilah, which is on the south of the Jeshimon?”
And now, according to all the desire of your soul, O king, to come down, come down; and it is for us to deliver him into the hand of the king.
And Saul said, Blessed are you of the LORD, for you have had compassion on me.
Go now, make yet more sure, and know and see the place where his foot shall be, who has seen him there; for it has been said to me, He is very crafty.

So look and know of all the hiding places where he hides himself there, and return to me with certainty, and I will go with you; and it shall be, if he is in the land, I will search him out among all the thousands of Judah.
So they arose and went to Ziph before Saul. And David and his men were in the wilderness of Maon, in the Arabah, to the right of the Jeshimon.

And Saul and his men went to seek him, and they told David; so he went down to the rock and dwelt in the wilderness of Maon. And Saul heard of it, and he pursued after David in the wilderness of Maon.

And Saul went on this side of the mountain, and David and his men on that side of the mountain; and David was hurrying to get away from before Saul, while Saul and his men were closing in on David and on his men to seize them.
But a messenger came to Saul, saying, “Hurry and go, for the Philistines have made a raid upon the land.”
So Saul returned from pursuing David, and went to meet the Philistines. Therefore they called that place the Rock of Divisions.
And David went up from there and dwelt in the strongholds of En-gedi.
And it came to pass, when Saul returned from following the Philistines, that they told him, saying, Behold, David is in the wilderness of En-gedi.
And Saul took three thousand chosen men out of all Israel, and went to seek David and his men upon the face of the rocks of the wild goats.
And he came to the sheepfolds by the way, where was a cave; and Saul went in to cover his feet, while David and his men were sitting in the innermost parts of the cave.

And the men of David said to him, “Behold, this is the day of which the LORD spoke to you, ‘Behold, I am giving your enemy into your hand, and you shall do to him as it seems good in your eyes.’” Then David arose and stealthily cut off the corner of Saul’s robe.
And it came to pass afterward, that David’s heart smote him, because he had cut off the corner of Saul’s robe.
And he said to his men, Far be it from me, from the LORD, that I should do this thing to my lord, the LORD’s anointed, to stretch out my hand against him, for he is the LORD’s anointed.
And David restrained his men with these words and did not permit them to rise against Saul. And Saul arose from the cave and went on his way.
And David said to Saul, Why do you listen to the words of men, saying, Behold, David seeks your harm?
And David said to Saul, Why do you listen to the words of men, saying, Behold, David seeks your harm?

Behold, this day your eyes have seen how the LORD gave you today into my hand in the cave, and some said to kill you, but my eye spared you, and I said, “I will not stretch out my hand against my lord, for he is the LORD’s anointed.”

See, my father, yes, see the corner of your robe in my hand. For when I cut off the corner of your robe, I did not kill you. Know then and see that there is no evil or transgression in my hand, and I have not sinned against you, yet you hunt my life to take it.
May the LORD judge between me and you, and may the LORD avenge me of you; but my hand shall not be against you.
As the ancient proverb says, “From the wicked comes forth wickedness,” but my hand shall not be against you.
After whom has the king of Israel come out? After whom are you pursuing? After a dead dog, after a single flea.
May the LORD therefore be judge, and decide between me and you; and may He see and plead my cause, and deliver me out of your hand.
And it came to pass, when David had made an end of speaking these words to Saul, that Saul said, “Is this your voice, my son David?” And Saul lifted up his voice and wept.
And he said to David, You are more righteous than I; for you have dealt well with me, whereas I have dealt evil with you.
And you have shown this day how you have dealt well with me, in that the LORD delivered me into your hand, and yet you did not kill me.
For if a man find his enemy, will he let him go in a good way? May the LORD repay you with good for what you have done to me this day.
And now, behold, I know that you shall surely reign, and the kingdom of Israel shall be established in your hand.
And now, swear to me by the LORD that you will not cut off my seed after me, and that you will not blot out my name from my father’s house.
And David swore to Saul. Then Saul went to his house, but David and his men went up to the stronghold.
And Samuel died; and all Israel gathered themselves together and lamented for him, and buried him in his house at Ramah. Then David arose and went down to the wilderness of Paran.

Now there was a man in Maon, and his work was in Carmel; and the man was very great, and he had three thousand sheep and a thousand goats. And it came to pass, while he was shearing his sheep in Carmel.

Now the name of the man was Nabal, and the name of his wife Abigail; and the woman was of good understanding and of beautiful form, but the man was harsh and evil in his dealings, and he was a Calebite.
And David heard in the wilderness that Nabal was shearing his sheep.
And David sent ten young men, and David said to the young men, “Go up to Carmel, and go to Nabal, and greet him in my name for peace.”
And thus shall you say to him who lives: Peace be to you, and peace be to your house, and peace be to all that is yours.
And now I have heard that you have shearers; now, the shepherds who are yours have been with us, we did not put them to shame, and nothing of theirs was missing all the days they were in Carmel.

Ask your young men, and they will tell you. Therefore let the young men find favor in your eyes, for we have come on a good day. Please give whatever your hand finds to your servants and to your son David.
And the young men of David came and spoke to Nabal according to all these words in the name of David, and then they rested.
And Nabal answered the servants of David and said, Who is David, and who is the son of Jesse? Today there are many servants who break away each man from before his master.
Shall I then take my bread and my water and my meat that I have slaughtered for my shearers, and give it to men whom I do not know from where they are?
So David’s young men turned to their way, and returned and came and told him according to all these words.

And David said to his men, “Gird on each man his sword.” So each man girded on his sword, and David also girded on his sword. And about four hundred men went up after David, while two hundred stayed by the baggage.
But one of the young men told Abigail, Nabal’s wife, saying, “Behold, David sent messengers from the wilderness to bless our master, and he railed at them.”
And the men were very good to us, and we were not shamed, nor did we miss anything, all the days we went about with them when we were in the field.
They were a wall to us both by night and by day, all the while we were with them keeping the flock.
And now, know and see what you will do, for evil is determined against our master and against all his house, and he is such a worthless man that one cannot speak to him.

Then Abigail made haste and took two hundred loaves of bread, and two skins of wine, and five sheep made ready, and five measures of parched grain, and a hundred clusters of raisins, and two hundred cakes of figs, and laid them upon donkeys.
And she said to her young men, “Pass on before me; behold, I am coming after you.” But she did not tell her husband Nabal.
And it came to pass, as she rode on the donkey and came down by the hidden side of the mountain, that behold, David and his men were coming down to meet her, and she met them.
Now David had said, “Surely in vain have I kept all that this man has in the wilderness, so that nothing of all that belongs to him was missing, and he has returned me evil for good.”
So may God do to the enemies of David, and more also, if I leave of all that belongs to him by the morning light even one who urinates against the wall.
When Abigail saw David, she hurried and dismounted from the donkey, and fell on her face before David and bowed herself to the ground.
She fell at his feet and said, “Upon me, my lord, upon me be the guilt. Please let your maidservant speak in your ears, and hear the words of your maidservant.”

Please, my lord, let not your heart regard this worthless man, this Nabal; for as his name is, so is he. Nabal is his name, and folly is with him. But I, your maidservant, did not see the young men of my lord whom you sent.

And now, my lord, as the LORD lives and as your soul lives, since the LORD has restrained you from coming into bloodshed and from saving yourself with your own hand, now let your enemies be as Nabal, and those who seek evil against my lord.
And now this blessing which your maidservant has brought to my lord, let it be given to the young men who walk at the feet of my lord.

Please forgive the transgression of your maidservant, for the LORD will surely make for my lord a sure house, because my lord fights the battles of the LORD, and evil shall not be found in you all your days.

And though a man rise up to pursue you and to seek your life, yet the life of my lord shall be bound in the bundle of the living with the LORD your God; and the life of your enemies, He shall sling out, as from the hollow of the sling.
And it shall come to pass, when the LORD has done for my lord according to all the good that He has spoken concerning you, and has appointed you ruler over Israel,

And this shall not be to you for staggering or for stumbling of heart to my lord, either that you have shed blood without cause, or that my lord has saved himself. And when the LORD has dealt well with my lord, then remember your handmaid.
And David said to Abigail, Blessed be the LORD, the God of Israel, who sent you this day to meet me.
And blessed be your discernment, and blessed be you, who have kept me this day from coming into bloodshed and from saving with my own hand.

Yet as the LORD lives, the God of Israel, who has restrained me from doing you evil, surely, if you had not hurried and come to meet me, there would not have been left to Nabal by the light of the morning even one who urinates against the wall.
And David received from her hand that which she had brought him, and he said to her, Go up in peace to your house; see, I have listened to your voice and have regarded your person.

And Abigail came to Nabal, and behold, he was holding a feast in his house like the feast of a king; and Nabal’s heart was merry within him, for he was very drunk. So she told him nothing, small or great, until the light of the morning.
And it came to pass in the morning, when the wine had gone out of Nabal, that his wife told him these things, and his heart died within him, and he became as a stone.
And it came to pass about ten days afterward, that the LORD struck Nabal, and he died.

And David heard that Nabal was dead, and he said, Blessed be the LORD, who has pleaded the cause of my reproach from the hand of Nabal, and has kept his servant from evil; for the LORD has returned the wickedness of Nabal upon his own head. And David sent and spoke with Abigail, to take her to himself for a wife.
And the servants of David came to Abigail at Carmel, and spoke to her, saying, “David has sent us to you, to take you to him as a wife.”
And she arose and bowed herself with her face to the ground, and said, Behold, your maidservant is as a handmaid to wash the feet of the servants of my lord.
And Abigail made haste and arose and rode upon a donkey, with her five maidens who went at her feet; and she went after the messengers of David, and became his wife.
David also took Ahinoam of Jezreel, and they both became his wives.
But Saul had given Michal his daughter, David’s wife, to Palti son of Laish, who was from Gallim.
Then the Ziphites came to Saul at Gibeah, saying, “Is not David hiding himself on the hill of Hachilah, which is before the wilderness?”
So Saul arose and went down to the wilderness of Ziph, and with him three thousand chosen men of Israel, to seek David in the wilderness of Ziph.
And Saul encamped in the hill of Hachilah, which is before the Jeshimon by the way. But David was dwelling in the wilderness, and he saw that Saul had come after him into the wilderness.
And David sent out spies, and he knew that Saul had indeed come to Nacon.

And David arose and came to the place where Saul had encamped; and David saw the place where Saul lay, and Abner son of Ner, the commander of his army. And Saul was lying within the circle of the camp, and the people were encamped around him.

And David answered and said to Ahimelech the Hittite and to Abishai the son of Zeruiah, brother of Joab, saying, Who will go down with me to Saul to the camp? And Abishai said, I will go down with you.
So David and Abishai came to the people by night, and behold, Saul lay sleeping within the circle, and his spear was stuck in the ground at his head, and Abner and the people were lying around him.

And Abishai said to David, “God has delivered your enemy today into your hand. Now therefore, let me strike him, I pray, with the spear to the earth at one stroke, and I will not strike him a second time.”
And David said to Abishai, Do not destroy him, for who can stretch out his hand against the LORD’s anointed and be guiltless?
And David said, As the LORD lives, surely the LORD shall strike him, or his day shall come and he will die, or he shall go down into battle and be swept away.
Far be it from me, by the LORD, that I should stretch out my hand against the LORD’s anointed. But now, take, I pray you, the spear that is at his head, and the cruse of water, and let us go.

And David took the spear and the jar of water from beside Saul’s head, and they went away; and no one saw, and no one knew, and no one awoke, for they were all sleeping, because a deep sleep from the LORD had fallen upon them.
And David passed over to the other side, and stood on the top of the hill afar off, a great space being between them.
And David called to the people and to Abner son of Ner, saying, “Will you not answer, Abner?” And Abner answered and said, “Who are you that calls to the king?”
And David said to Abner, “Are you not a man? And who is like you in Israel? Why then have you not kept watch over your lord the king? For one of the people came in to destroy the king your lord.”

Not good is this thing that you have done. As the LORD lives, you are sons of death, because you have not kept watch over your lord, over the LORD’s anointed. And now, see where the king’s spear is, and the jug of water that was at his head.
And Saul recognized the voice of David and said, Is this your voice, my son David? And David said, It is my voice, my lord the king.
And he said, Why is my lord pursuing after his servant? For what have I done, or what evil is in my hand?

And now, let my lord the king, I pray, hear the words of his servant. If it is the LORD who has stirred you up against me, let Him accept an offering; but if it is the sons of men, cursed are they before the LORD, for they have driven me out this day that I should have no share in the inheritance of the LORD, saying, “Go, serve other gods.”
And now, let not my blood fall to the earth away from the presence of the LORD; for the king of Israel has come out to seek a single flea, as one hunts a partridge in the mountains.
And Saul said, I have sinned; return, my son David, for I will not harm you again, because my life was precious in your eyes this day. Behold, I have acted foolishly and have erred exceedingly.
And David answered and said, Behold the king’s spear; let one of the young men come over and take it.
And the LORD will render to each man his righteousness and his faithfulness, for the LORD delivered you today into my hand, but I would not stretch out my hand against the LORD’s anointed.
And behold, as your life was highly esteemed this day in my eyes, so may my life be highly esteemed in the eyes of the LORD, and may He deliver me out of every distress.
And Saul said to David, Blessed are you, my son David; you shall surely do, and you shall surely prevail. So David went on his way, and Saul returned to his place.

And David said in his heart, Now I shall perish one day by the hand of Saul; there is nothing better for me than that I should escape swiftly into the land of the Philistines, and Saul will despair of me, to seek me any more in all the border of Israel; so shall I escape out of his hand.
Then David arose and passed over, he and the six hundred men who were with him, to Achish son of Maoch, king of Gath.
And David dwelt with Achish at Gath, he and his men, each with his household, David with his two wives, Ahinoam the Jezreelite, and Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite.
And it was told Saul that David had fled to Gath, and he no more again went on seeking him.

And David said to Achish, If now I have found favor in your eyes, let them give me a place in one of the country towns, that I may dwell there; for why should your servant dwell in the royal city with you?
So Achish gave him Ziklag that day; therefore Ziklag has belonged to the kings of Judah to this day.
And the number of the days that David dwelt in the country of the Philistines was a year and four months.
And David went up, he and his men, and raided the Geshurites and the Girzites and the Amalekites, for they were the inhabitants of the land from of old, as you go to Shur, even to the land of Egypt.
And David struck the land, and left alive neither man nor woman, and took the sheep and the oxen and the donkeys and the camels and the garments, and returned and came to Achish.
And Achish said, Against whom have you made a raid today? And David said, Against the Negeb of Judah, and against the Negeb of the Jerahmeelite, and against the Negeb of the Kenite.

And David would not let man or woman live, to bring to Gath, saying, “Lest they tell about us, saying, ‘So did David, and so was his manner all the days that he dwelt in the country of the Philistines.’”
And Achish trusted in David, saying, “He has surely made himself loathsome to his people, to Israel; therefore he shall be my servant forever.”

And it came to pass in those days that the Philistines gathered their camps for war, to fight against Israel. And Achish said to David, “You surely know that you shall go out with me in the army, you and your men.”
And David said to Achish, “Therefore you shall know what your servant will do.” And Achish said to David, “Therefore I will make you keeper of my head all the days.”
Now Samuel was dead, and all Israel had lamented him and buried him in Ramah, even in his own city. And Saul had put away the mediums and the wizards out of the land.
And the Philistines gathered themselves together and came and encamped in Shunem; and Saul gathered all Israel, and they encamped in Gilboa.
And when Saul saw the camp of the Philistines, he was afraid, and his heart trembled greatly.
And Saul inquired of the LORD, but the LORD did not answer him, neither by dreams, nor by the Urim, nor by the prophets.

And Saul said to his servants, “Seek for me a woman who is mistress of a familiar spirit, that I may go to her and inquire of her.” And his servants said to him, “Behold, there is a woman who is mistress of a familiar spirit at En-dor.”

So Saul disguised himself and put on other garments, and he went, he and two men with him, and they came to the woman by night. And he said, “Conjure for me, I pray you, by a familiar spirit, and bring up for me the one whom I shall name to you.”
And the woman said to him, Behold, you know what Saul has done, how he has cut off the mediums and the spiritists from the land; and why then are you laying a snare for my life, to cause me to die?
And Saul swore to her by the LORD, saying, As the LORD lives, no guilt shall befall you in this matter.
And the woman said, “Whom shall I bring up for you?” And he said, “Bring up Samuel for me.”
And when the woman saw Samuel, she cried out with a loud voice; and the woman spoke to Saul, saying, “Why have you deceived me? For you are Saul.”
And the king said to her, “Do not be afraid; for what did you see?” And the woman said to Saul, “I saw a godlike being ascending out of the earth.”

And he said to her, What is his form? And she said, An old man is coming up, and he is wrapped in a robe. Then Saul knew that it was Samuel, and he bowed with his face to the ground and prostrated himself.

And Samuel said to Saul, Why have you disturbed me, to bring me up? And Saul said, I am in great distress, and the Philistines are warring against me, and God has turned away from me and answers me no more, neither by the hand of the prophets nor by dreams; therefore I have called you, to make known to me what I shall do.
And Samuel said, Why then do you ask of me, seeing the LORD has turned from you and has become your adversary?
And the LORD has done for himself as he spoke by my hand, and the LORD has torn the kingdom out of your hand and given it to your neighbor, to David.
Because you did not listen to the voice of the LORD, and did not execute His fierce wrath upon Amalek, therefore the LORD has done this thing to you this day.

And the LORD will also give Israel with you into the hand of the Philistines, and tomorrow you and your sons shall be with me; the LORD will also give the camp of Israel into the hand of the Philistines.

Then Saul made haste and fell full length upon the earth, and was very afraid because of the words of Samuel; and there was no strength in him, for he had eaten no bread all that day and all that night.

And the woman came to Saul and saw that he was greatly dismayed, and she said to him, Behold, your maidservant has listened to your voice, and I have put my life in my hand and have listened to the words which you spoke to me.
And now, I pray you, also listen to the voice of your maidservant, and let me set before you a piece of bread, and eat, that strength may be in you when you go on your way.
But he refused and said, “I will not eat.” Then his servants, together with the woman, pressed him, and he listened to their voice. So he arose from the earth and sat upon the bed.
Now the woman had a fatted calf in the house; and she made haste and slaughtered it, and she took flour and kneaded it, and baked unleavened bread of it.
She brought it near before Saul and before his servants, and they ate. Then they rose up and went away that night.
Now the Philistines gathered together all their armies to Aphek, and Israel was encamped by the spring which is in Jezreel.
And the lords of the Philistines were passing on by hundreds and by thousands, and David and his men were passing on in the rear with Achish.

Then the princes of the Philistines said, “What are these Hebrews doing here?” And Achish said to the princes of the Philistines, “Is not this David, the servant of Saul king of Israel, who has been with me these days or these years, and I have found no fault in him from the day he fell over to me until this day?”

But the princes of the Philistines were angry with him, and the princes of the Philistines said to him, “Send the man back, that he may return to his place where you have appointed him, and let him not go down with us to battle, lest in the battle he become an adversary to us. For with what might this fellow reconcile himself to his lord? Would it not be with the heads of these men?”
Is not this David, of whom they sang one to another in dances, saying, Saul has struck down his thousands, and David his ten thousands?

And Achish called David and said to him, As the LORD lives, you are upright, and your going out and your coming in with me in the camp has been good in my eyes; for I have found no evil in you from the day of your coming to me until this day. Nevertheless, in the eyes of the princes you are not good.
So now return and go in peace, that you do not displease the lords of the Philistines.

And David said to Achish, “But what have I done? And what have you found in your servant from the day that I have been before you until this day, that I may not go and fight against the enemies of my lord the king?”
And Achish answered and said to David, I know that you are good in my eyes, as an angel of God; nevertheless, the princes of the Philistines have said, He shall not go up with us to the battle.
So now rise early in the morning, you and the servants of your lord who came with you; yes, rise early in the morning, and when it is light for you, depart.
So David rose early, he and his men, to depart in the morning to return to the land of the Philistines; and the Philistines went up to Jezreel.
And it came to pass, when David and his men came to Ziklag on the third day, that the Amalekites had made a raid upon the Negev and upon Ziklag, and had struck Ziklag and burned it with fire.
And they took captive the women that were in it, from small even to great; they did not put anyone to death, but carried them off and went on their way.
And David came, and the men who were with him, to the city, and behold, it was burned with fire, and their wives and their sons and their daughters were taken captive.
Then David and the people who were with him lifted up their voice and wept, until they had no strength in them to weep.
And the two wives of David were taken captive: Ahinoam the Jezreelite, and Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite.

And David was greatly distressed, for the people spoke of stoning him, because the soul of all the people was bitter, each man for his sons and for his daughters; but David strengthened himself in the LORD his God.
And David said to Abiathar the priest, the son of Ahimelech, “Bring near to me, I pray, the ephod.” And Abiathar brought the ephod near to David.
And David inquired of the LORD, saying, “Shall I pursue after this band? Shall I overtake it?” And He said to him, “Pursue, for you shall surely overtake, and you shall surely deliver.”
So David went, he and the six hundred men who were with him, and they came to the brook Besor, where those who were left behind stayed.
But David pursued, he and four hundred men; for two hundred men stayed behind, who were too faint to pass over the brook Besor.
And they found an Egyptian man in the field, and brought him to David, and gave him bread and he ate, and they made him drink water.
And they gave him a piece of a fig cake and two clusters of raisins, and he ate; and his spirit returned to him, for he had eaten no bread and drunk no water three days and three nights.

David said to him, “To whom do you belong, and from where are you?” And he said, “I am a young man of Egypt, servant to an Amalekite man, and my master left me, for I fell sick this day three days ago.”
We made a raid upon the Negev of the Cherethites, and upon that which belongs to Judah, and upon the Negev of Caleb, and Ziklag we burned with fire.

And David said to him, Bring me down to this band. And he said, Swear to me by God that you will not put me to death, and that you will not deliver me into the hand of my master, and I will bring you down to this band.

And he brought him down, and behold, they were spread abroad over all the land, eating and drinking and feasting with all the great spoil that they had taken out of the land of the Philistines and out of the land of Judah.
And David struck them from the twilight even until the evening of the next day, and not a man of them escaped, except four hundred young men who rode upon camels and fled.
And David rescued all that the Amalekites had taken; and David delivered his two wives.
And nothing of theirs was missing, from the small even to the great, and sons and daughters, and spoil, and all that they had taken for themselves; David brought back all.
And David took all the flock and the herd; they drove them before that other livestock, and they said, This is David’s spoil.

And David came to the two hundred men who had been too faint to follow after David, and whom they had made to remain at the brook Besor; and they went out to meet David, and to meet the people who were with him. And David drew near to the people and greeted them in peace.

Then all the wicked and worthless men of those who went with David answered and said, “Because they did not go with us, we will not give them anything of the spoil that we have delivered, except that each man may take his wife and his children and go.”
But David said, You shall not do so, my brothers, with that which the LORD has given us, who has preserved us and delivered into our hand the band that came against us.
And who would listen to you in this matter? For as the share of him who goes down to the battle, so shall be the share of him who stays by the baggage; together they shall divide alike.
And it came to pass from that day and onward, that he made it a statute and an ordinance for Israel, to this very day.
And David came to Ziklag, and sent of the spoil to the elders of Judah, to his friends, saying, Behold, for you a blessing from the spoil of the enemies of the LORD.
To those who were in Bethel, and to those who were in Ramoth of the Negev, and to those who were in Jattir.

Now the Philistines were fighting against Israel, and the men of Israel fled from before the Philistines, and the slain fell on Mount Gilboa.
And the Philistines pressed hard upon Saul and upon his sons; and the Philistines struck down Jonathan and Abinadab and Malchi-shua, the sons of Saul.
And the battle pressed hard upon Saul, and the archers found him, men with the bow, and he was sorely wounded by the archers.

And Saul said to his armor-bearer, Draw your sword and thrust me through with it, lest these uncircumcised come and thrust me through and abuse me. But his armor-bearer would not, for he was very afraid. So Saul took the sword and fell upon it.
When his armor-bearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell upon his sword and died with him.
So Saul died, and his three sons, and his armor-bearer, and all his men together on that day.

And the men of Israel who were on the other side of the valley, and those who were on the other side of the Jordan, saw that the men of Israel fled, and that Saul and his sons were dead, and they forsook the cities and fled; and the Philistines came and dwelt in them.
And it came to pass on the next day, when the Philistines came to strip the slain, that they found Saul and his three sons fallen on Mount Gilboa.
And they cut off his head and stripped off his armor, and sent into the land of the Philistines all around, to proclaim it in the house of their idols and among the people.
And they put his armor in the house of the Ashtaroth, and fastened his body to the wall of Beth-shan.
And when the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead heard what the Philistines had done to Saul,
Then all the valiant men arose and went all night, and they took the body of Saul and the bodies of his sons from the wall of Beth-shan, and came to Jabesh and burned them there.
And they took their bones and buried them under the tamarisk tree in Jabesh, and fasted seven days.
